div1.head: Lecture: Sanitation Work in Cuba, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 23, 1912
div1.p:
Keans lecture at Army Med. School
May 23, 1912
Sanitation in Cuba.
SECOND INTERVENTION IN CUBA OCT. 1, 1906 to Jan. 29, 1909:

As has been mentioned in speaking of the sanitary work of the 1st
Intervention, it was performed by a number of independent sanitary workers
acting under the different local military authorities but without the
assistance and unity of effort which would have been afforded by a central
sanitary organization. This work, although without uniformity of method
or coherence of organization, was so well done that it was apparently
not reali[unclear]ntil the end of the American Military Government of Inter-
vention was in sight and the date of May 20, 1902, had been fixed for
the establishment of the Cuban Republic that a sanitary department would be
necessary for the Cuban Government in order to maintain good health con-
ditions and carry out its obligations as regards sanitation which were
imposed upon it by the United States in the Platt amendment to the Cuban con-
stitution. Accordingly, General Wood, as well as I recall, early in
May, organized a Commission which was instructed to draw up a sanitary
law organizing a national department of health and describing its powers.
This commission was composed of Col. Gorgas and myself, both of us being
then Majors; Dr. A. H. Glennan of the Marine Hospital Service, and

The sanitary law prepared by this commission was published as Orders No.
159, Hdqrs. Dept. of Cuba, Havana, May 17, 1902, three days before the
withdrawal of the American Government and the establishment of the Cuban
Republic. It provided for a superior sanitary board composed of five
active members and six honorary members, which latter were the chief
of the Marine Hospital Service of the Island, a member of the Academy of
Sciences of Havana, a member of the faculty of the University of Havana,
president of the tuberculosis league, a member of the board of education,
and a legally qualified lawyer. The honorary members of the board were
- 2 -
2
not entitle to vote. The president and executive officer of the board
was the chief sanitary officer of the Island. This board had general su-
pervision of all health matters throughout the island and was charged with
making sanitary investigations, the publication of useful information on
sanitary subjects, the enforcement of sanitary laws including laws regulat-
ing the practice of the medical profession, pharmacy, dentistry, midwifery,
embalming and laws regulating prostitution, and for the control of offen-
sive and dangerous trades. It had also supervision of all local boards of
health and a general supervisory authority known in the Spanish law as
“alta inspeccion” over all eleemosynary institutions, prisons, hospitals,
and other public institutions. It was charged with the collection of vital
statistics, the control of epidemic diseases, of interior quarantine regu-
lations, the establishment and administration of biological, chemical and
bacteriological laboratories, and the enforcement of vaccination.

I urged strongly the importance of making sanitation a separate depart-
ment with representation in the cabinet, but Ceneral Wood was averse to an
enlargement of the cabinet, and it was made a subordinate bureau under the
Secretaryship of Gubernacion, in which my former department of Beneficencia
or Charities was another bureau. Another point which I urged was the logi-
cal appropriateness and administrative advantage of having marine quaran-
tine placed under the Sanitary Department, but the Marine Hospital Service
of the United States was opposed to this and its representative on the board
Dr. Glennan, successfully opposed it, and it was left under the Treasury, as
in the United States. Cuba was destined to pay dearly for this in 1905 when
by lack of co-ordination between these two lines of sanitary defence yellow
fever was re-introduced into Havana from New Orleans.

It took nearly two years for this organization to become effective and
to prepare its sanitary code, which was a very elaborate one, based on Euro-
pean models and quite unsuited to small towns and rural communities. The
- 3 -
3
small towns suffered much more from sanitary neglects than did Havana be-
cause for the latter money was furnished by the national government, while
local boards of health in the small towns had to depend upon the entirely
inadequate appropriations of town councils and were submissive to political
and personal influences of every kind. Thus the extensive powers given by
the decree of General Wood to the national board existed without the neces-
sary machinery by which these powers could be administered, operating as
the board was compelled to do through the local boards of health, over
whose personnel and finances the central authority had but nominal control.

The Cuban territory is divided into municipalities, each of which
embraces a certain geographical area, both urban and rural. Each of these
municipalities is governed by a town council or Ayuntamiento and for each
of these municipalities was provided a local sanitary board of three mem-
bers. These local boards were governed by general sanitary regulations
adopted by the superior sanitary board and had general supervision of all
health matters of the municipality. The funds needed for the sanitary
services of the cities and of the other sanitary activities of the local
boards were to be provided by appropriations by the municipalities, ex-
cept in the case of Havana where the national government supported the
local sanitary establishment which was immediately under the chief sani-
tary officer. The Ayuntamientos, much like the majority of town councils
in the United States, had other objects upon which to spend their money
in which they took much greater interest than in sanitary matters and
therefore the sanitary activities in the Cuban cities other than Havana
practically ceased after General Wood's departure from the Island, except
in the capital and except for the stimulus of occasional appropriations
from the national government for sanitary work in the other larger towns
when conditions became very bad or yellow fever made its appearance. The
national board, however, accomplished much excellent work under the presi-
- 4 -
4
dency of Estrada Palma, although after the manner of all boards it was a
defective administrative agency.

A successful insurrection in August, 1906, compelled Estrada Palma
to call on the United States to intervene in accordance with our treaty
right and the Secretary of War, Mr. Taft, landed and assumed the reins of
government Sept. 20, 1906. He cabled for me to report to him at once and
placed me in general supervisory charge of the sanitary department. Being
mindful of the importance of a right start I said “Shall I report to you
direct, Mr. Secretary”, and as he hesitated I added “in the former inter-
vention IGorgas reported directly to General Wood”. He said the precious “Yes”
which established the independence of sanitation for the time being and I
took my way to the familiar old Maestranza de Artilleria, where both Gorgas
and I had had our offices in the first intervention. There I found the
Chief Sanitary Officer, my old and dear friend Dr. Carlos Finley, the ori-
ginal champion of the mosquito theory, to whom I imparted my commission and
handed the Secretary's brief note. After greeting me with that exquisite
courtesy which is one of the strongest characteristics of this fine old
man he asked me what were my powers. I told him that I conceived them to
be those of a cabinet secretary. Then he asked what would be my title. -
There I was stumped and I asked him for a suggestion. - “I am directed by
the Secretary”, said he, “to follow your advice in all things so how would
the title of Adviser do.” This seemed fitting and not only did I keep it
during the entire intervention but all the other Army officers and civilians
who were placed at the head of the other departments of the governments were
also given the title of Adviser instead of that of Secretary.

I found Gorgas' organization in the City of Havana largely intact,
but it had evidently lost its discipline in the four years of immunity from
yellow fever, and although yellow fever had for the last year been present,
in the island, it had been unable to regain its discipline and effectiveness.

There were 20 sanitary inspectors whose work was reinforced by a hord of un-
instructed and ignorant laborers who wandered about the city with oil cans
pouring petroleum into every rat hole and puddle.

div1.p:
The chief confidence of Drs. Finlay and GorgasGuiteras was placed in the divi-
sion of disinfection where there was a large and well-trained force of men
conducting fumigations. The operation of this brigade I made little change
in, although in my opinion the importance of their work was entirely secon-
dary to mosquito prevention. The division of sanitary inspection, La Prince's
old organization, which did the house inspections for mosquito larvae, I found
much disorganized and its shortcomings, which had quite escaped the notice
of the sanitary authorities of Havana, were directly responsible for the
infection being able to take root again. To it, therefore, I gave my close
and unremitting attention. There were 20 sanitary inspectors whose work was reinforced by a hord of un-
instructed and ignorant laborers who wandered about the city with oil cans
pouring petroleum into every rat hole and puddle. The number of district inspectors was promptly
increased to 42, one for every sanitary district into which I divided the
city, while there were a number of auxillary inspectors who could be thrown
into districts which required special attention. Each district inspector
was informed that he would be held to strict accountability for the condi-
tion of his district and this responsibility was emphasized by the summary
dismissal of those who were found negligent. The inspectors were given
credentials and a neat uniform which enabled the house-holders to distin-
guish them from irresponsible persons and which also enabled the super-
vising inspectors whom I placed over groups of districts to readily observe
those who showed a disposition to sit in the cafes rather than search for
stegomyia larvae.

By the next spring the mosquito work was well in hand in the city, the
stegomyias were very scarce, and cases only appeared sporadically at
6
15.
-4
sufficient intervals to furnish an excuse for maintaining quarantines on
the part of the United States. The disease was continually reintroduced into
Havana from the country districts, but I made no effort to prevent this be-
cause the coming of patients to the great public hospitals of the city where
they were kept in screened rooms often gave me the first intimation of the
development of the new foci in the country and small towns. I was perfectly
confident of my ability to prevent an epidemic in Havana, although it was full
of non-immunes

Another peculiarity of this invasion or yellow fever, for it was
never generally epidemic, was the small number of cases that occurred
and the remarkable way in which they were spread over the period of
three years and three months between the appearance of the disease in
Havana in October, 1905, and the final occurrence of the last cases in
the province of Oriente in the neighborhood of Santiago in the fall of
1908. The entire number of cases during all this time was only 359.
This number is made up of a number of scattered cases throughout the
island, together with several small localized epidemics such as that in
Havana in November and December, 1905, that in the towns in the south-
east part of the Province of Havana in 1906, an outbreak in Cienfuegos
in the summer of 1907, and one in the iron mines of Darquiri in 1909.
Contrast this with the disease in Havana in 1900, when there were 1240
cases and 305 deaths. The efforts of the sanitary department invar-
iably brought each outbreak to a close with the exception of an occasional
sporadic case as soon as a local organization could be effected and the
number of mosquitoes reduced to a point which Gorgas called “the yellow
fever point.” Now please observe that as soon as the mosquito reduc-
tion reached this point in Havana in 1901 yellow fever disappeared not
only from Havana but from all of Cuba, whereas no such good fortune at-
tended the mosquito work in Havana in 1907.

The disease spread, however, during the year to every province in the
island with the exception of the most western, but was promptly stamped out in
the larger cities with the exception of Cienfuegos where a sharp epidemic oc-
curred in the fall of 1907, and Santiago where the infection smouldered until
the spring of 1908. Conquared in the centers of population, the disease
adopted the tactics of the revolutionists and took to the woods and this ex-
tension to the woodsvillages and plantations broughtup new and troublesome problems
which were not known to the first Intervention.

It was certain that the work against yellow fever in Cuba was equally
thorough in detail and on a wider scale than that conducted in Havana and the
other more important cities in 1901. Why was it not followed by the same
prompt success? in 1907 and why did not yellow fever at that time hang on in
the rural districts? The disease having been so long endemic in Cuba
the native Cuban population was then truely an immune one, and yellow
fever rarely prevailed in Cuba, but lay in wait in the sea ports for the
none- immune immigrants who were as a rule not long in finding either
immunity or death. But since 1900 this process had been checked, and
the non-immune population of Cuba had increased with great rapidity. The
number of immigrants, chiefly Spaniards, had averaged nearly 30,000 a year
and in the last two years amounted to 88,000. The native white population
8
had also increased with great rapidity & if we accept the theory of Guiteras that
the white Cuban Child is born non-immune, this still greater source of supply of
non-immunes must be added - amounting to 7800 annually for Habana and
66,500 for the Island.

Here I might allude to the well known theory of Guiteras as to
the immunity of Cuban children which is now generally accepted, although
when it was first announced it was much disputed by Cuban physicians.
It is simply that immunity to yellow fever is acquired by Cuban children
in the same way that immunity to other diseases is acquired by most people
to the ordinary childrens diseases, viz: by an attack in infancy, this
attack being usually mild and not recognized as yellow fever but being
disguised under such diagnoses as dengue, malaria, or calentura.
Even the severe attacks marked by jaundice, black vomit, and even death,
were not formerly diagnosed as yellow fever by Cuban physicians so con-
vinced were they that by some heaven bestowed gift the Cuban children
were immune to it and so such cases were habitually diagnosed as feibre
de borras. The only difficulty in the way of acceptance of this theory,
and it always appeared to me a very real one, is the fact that this would
have required an enormous number of cases every year to keep up the
immunity of the Cuban people. In commenting upon an outbreak of 400
cases of fever which occurred in October at Columbia Barracks and which
the medical officer, Dr. Saleeby? Salene, who made a report of the epidemic, was
inclined to consider yellow fever, I made the following remarks:-
Saleeby

“The short mild continued fever of about a week's duration
with a descending temperature curve from the first or second day, is
an old acquintance. Whether this is an acclimatizing, i.e., a very
mild sporadic form of yellow fever, is an interesting and important
subject for investigation. Dr. H.R.Carter, Marine-Hospital Service,
recently in conversation advanced the following facts, which are sug-
gestive in this connection: All quarantine authorities agree that ten
years' residence in Havana entitles a man to be considered immune; that
is, that in that time he will certainly have had yellow fever or an
immunizing fever. The Spanish immigration -nonmilitary - for years past
has been on an average 15,000 a year. Of these, by a moderate estimate,
5,000 make their home in Havana. Approximately 5,000 children are born
in Havana each year. Supposing that half of these die before they
reach the age of 10, we have 2,500 a year to acquire immunity in the same
way that the Spaniards do. Thus we should have 7,500 cases a year of
immunizing (yellow) fever. The average annual civilian death rate in
Havana from yellow fever is 210, which, with a death rate of, say,
30 per cent, would give 700 cases of clinically recognized yellow fever
a year. Thus we would have left 6,800 persons a year who acquire
9
-2-
immunity through fevers not to be recognized as yellow fever in the
home of that disease.”

In the five years between the two outbreaks some 350,000 children
had been born in Cuba and about 38,000 in Havana, and as this
element would then constitute probably the largest non-immune element
in the Island, it should have furnished most of the cases of yellow
fever, but on the contrary I do not recall more than three cases in
children during the second intervention. This is a phenomenon for
which I have no explanation which it is at all satisfactory and when I
was asked if I accepted Guiteras' theory I would say that I believed
it on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, but rejected it on Tuesday, Thurs-
day and Saturday. Sundays I deliused to think of it.

div1.p:
The number of non-immunes had already become sufficient to support a
yellow fever epidemic in alsmot any town or large plantation in the island,
and the increase of the facilities for communication by rail and by the con-
struction of good public roads, together with the migratory habits of the
Spanish laborers furnish a ready means for the distribution of the infection,
which means existed to a far less degree in 1901. The sanitary forces had
to pursue the enemy into the country and whereever a case of yellow fever was
recognized, expert diagnostitions and brigades of men trained in the technique
of fumigation and mosquito work were went from Havana to conduct operations
against the enemy. These methods kept the infection from assuming great pre0
portions but failed promptly to extinguish it in 1907. The reasons for this failure
were two, the first was the lack of agencies for the discovering and reporting
of cases outside of the large cities, the second, the lack of trained men to
carry out carefully, conscientiously and thoroughly, the work of mosquito pre-
vention. No thisin the small times

Nothing is more difficult than the recognition of mild cases of yellow
fever. Cases constantly occurred in Havana which puzzled the board of diagnosis,
probably the most expert body in the knowledge of this disease in the world.
Also it must be borne in mind that a large proportion of cases and, probably in
Cuban children a very large majority, are mild, and so difficult or impossible
of diagnosis with the help of all the resources of medical art. In the rural
municipalities little attention was paid to mild attacks of fever and the
physicians were not accustomed to employ the diagnostic aids of urinalisis and
blood examination, and had neither the apparatus nor the technical training for
so doing. Therefore, only the minority of grave or fatal cases were necognized
17/
-6-
11
and reported, and the infection spread unchecked by preventive measures until
a death gave the alarm. While the sanitary department could send trained
parties to direct works of fumigation in recognized foci, the fundamental
work of mosquito prevention required permanent garrisons of trained men in
every town and village and even in the great sugar and tobaco plantations.

Such a plan of campaign can be conducted where the area is small
and the pecuniary resources practically unlimited as in the strip ten miles
wide and fifty miles long which constitutes the canal zone at Panama, but
it was of course out of the question to conduct such intensive methods
over the 44 000 square miles of Cuban territory, and was far beyond the
resources of the Cuban Treasury. I have had, therefore, to limit my
campaign of mosquito prevention to municipalities where yellow fever had
appeared until a new and more prefect and centralized sanitary organization
gave me the central department immediate control over all the sanitary agen-
cies of the Island. This reorganization will be described later.
c⟩ Here might be mentioned a controversy with the Quarantine authorities of U.S.

This was affected by the complete reorganization of the sanitary de-
partment from top to bottom, which was affected by Governor Magoon's decree
#894, signed August 26, 1907. The objects accomplished by this decree were:

1 - The abolition of the local and municipal boards of health and
the transfer of all powers previously vested in them to national officials
called local sanitary officers who are appointed by the President.

2 - The assumption by the state of the cost of all municipal works
and service such as street cleaning, the removal of garbage, the suppression
of nuisances, and the prevention of epidemics. To relieve in some measure
the burden upon the national treasury it is required that the municipal
government should refund to the state one-tenth of their total incomes for
each year in part payment for these sanitary services.

3 - The supreme administrative authority in the sanitary department
a⟩ See Doc. “Quarantine against yellow fever in Cuba” p. 20 et seq.
18.
-7-
12
was transferred from the national board of health where it formerly was vested
to the chief sanitary officer who was made in fact the administrative authority
of the sanitary department. The national board of health was retained in
an advisory capacity.

By another decree the Marine quarantine service which constitutes the first
line of national defense against epidemics was made an intergral part of the
sanitary department, a step whichas I had strongly urged in his law of May,
1902. ✓Finally the organization of the sanitary department was perfected
and completed by joining to it the department of charities which has charge
in Cuba of all the numerous public hospitals, the care of the insane, the
responsibility for all dependent children and those who have been convicted
of crime and of all in general of all elemosinary and charitable institu-
tions and funds. This department called now “The Direction of Beneficencia”
is joined with the Direction of Sanitation to make the Department of Sanita-
tion and Charities, under a Secretary who is a Cabinet Officer.

The complete Department of Sanitation and Charities as shown by
the diagram consists of the Direction of Sanitation
Direction of Charities
Board of Sanitation and Charities.

The Direccion of Sanitation is under a chief executive officer
called the Director, which position is now filled by the well known
yellow fever specialist, Dr. Juan Guiteras. It is divided into the
following bureaus:-

(1) The Central Bureau, which has supervision over the sanitary
services of all municipalities in the Republic, except Havana; of the
various laboratories, bacteriological, chemical and bromological; of
the hospitals for contagious diseases; of the sanitoria and dispensaries
for tuberculosis; the vaccine stations, and the expert personnel of the
Department.

(2) Bureau of Sanitary Services of Havana. This bureau con-
tains complete the old sanitary organization of Gorgas with some addi-
tions and its sphere of activity is limited as indicated by its name to
the municipality of Havana, embracing a population of some 400,000 persons.

(3) General Affairs and Quarantine: This bureau has charge of
regulations for the practice of the professions of medicine, veterinary
medicine, pharmacy, dental surgery, obstetrics, embalming, undertakers,
and the control of dangerous and noxious industries. One division of it
also has charge of the marine quarantine service.

(4) Special Hygiene: This bureau has charge of matters connected
with the control and regulation of prostitution and the prevention of
venereal diseases in the cities of the Republic. This service of special
hygiene as it is called is entirely self-supporting, receiving no appro-
priation from the State, it is supported by fees which are required of
prostitutes for the weekly physical examinations and by fines and taxes
-2-
14
which are levied upon houses of prostitution or assignation. It
supports lock-hospitals for the confinement and treatment of diseased
public women and in Havana at least it supports free dispensaries where
men may receive free treatment, day and night, for venereal diseases.

(5) Statistics and Correspondence. The duties of this bureau
are suggested by its name. It is charged among other things with the
collection and publication of the vital statistics of the Republic.

(6) Personnel, Property and Accounts. The functions of this
bureau are indicated by its name, it being charged with the details of
all the functions of the internal administration of the Department.

The Direccion of Charities is under a Director who is a superior
chief of administration in the official hierarchy of Cuba and it is
the Department of which I had charge during the last year of the 1st
Intervention and upon which I am glad to believe that I left a certain
impress in bringing it in line with the modern ideas of scientific
charitable organization. It is divided into four bureaus:-

(1) Administration and Inspection: Charged with all matters
relating to the administrative and legal affairs of charitable institu-
tions. It has also charge of the correspondence of the Direccion.

(2) Hospitals and asylums. This bureau has charge of matters
of a technical character pertaining to the hospitals, asylums, charitable
institutions and schools for nurses.

(3) The Bureau of Minors is charged with the care and correction
of destitute and delinquent children. It secures the adoption of
orphans by private families and looks after their interests as long as
they are minors.

(4) Personnel, Property and Accounts. Its functions are similar
to those of the like bureau in the Direccion of Sanitation.

The National Board of Sanitation and Charities is organized as
follows:

Director of Sanitation
Director of Charities
Chief of the Quarantine Service
President of the Board of Infectious Diseases.
Dean of the Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy of the University of Havana
President of the League against Tuberculosis
President of the Economic Society of Friends of the Country
Local Chief of Sanitation of Havana
President of the Special Hygiene Commission; and

Four additional members to be appointed freely by the President of
the Republic, one of them to be a lawyer qualified to practice in the
Republic, and another, a civil engineer.

The President of the Board shall be the Director of Sanitation,
and the Director of Charities shall be Vice-President, and in the absence
of both, the oldest member. The Chief Clerk of the Direccion of San-
itation shall act as Secretary, in accordance with the provisions of
article 298 of this law.

These changes and additions were all codified and published at the
end of the second intervention as chapter 8 of title 3 of the organic
law of the Executive Power, the organic act which states and defines the
authority of all the different branches of the government. [unclear] Thus Cuba
has obtained a goal in the matter of public health organization which
we in the United States are still struggling for and which the American
Public Health Medical Association, the Committee of One Hundred, and iin
general all medical and socialogical associations are now demanding of
Congress.

This legislation has already had its influence upon sanitary
organization elsewhere. The essential feature of the substitution of
sanitary officers for local sanitary boards has been adopted for the
Sanitary Department of the Philippines and the entire law with but few
changes has been recently enacted as the new sanitary law of Porto Rico.
Within the last week I have been called upon to furnish a copy to the
President, Board of Health of the State of Louisiana to be used as a model
in the revision of their sanitary law.

J. R. Kean
